After personally witnessing the breathtaking beauties of Earth, the sensitive Silver Surfer rebels against his master in roaming the cosmos for planets to feed on. His rebellion sentences him to prison within Earth. Thus, this tragic, soul-torn, sentient being proves to be a benevolent alien; a contemplative philosopher; a gentle poet; an astute journalist, pure in heart and true in spirit, who shows us how Earth truly is a Garden of Eden.

A subway terminal passenger who only wanted a more human world; a sensitive, simple stranger tired of society's hustling and bustling, scurrying and hurrying through life. This unnamed darling who wanted every poet's heartrending hope to come true: to slow down the pace, smell the flowers, connect with friends and strangers, soak the atmosphere, loiter in the sun, harken to people's hearts, cherish human moments. But we know all too well the polite, efficient, robotic life we manuever through. Yet a beautiful tender young lady, able to stop one's rushing ways, opens to us the lost beauty of simply surviving day to day.
Characters.Quote: Hey. Could we do that again? I know we haven't met, but I don't want to be an ant. You know? I mean, it's like we go through life with our antennas bouncing off one another, continously on ant autopilot, with nothing really human required of us. Stop. Go. Walk here. Drive there. All action basically for survival. All communication simply to keep this ant colony buzzing along in an efficient, polite manner. "Here's your change." "Paper or plastic?' "Credit or debit?" "You want ketchup with that?" I don't want a straw. I want real human moments. I want to see you. I want you to see me. I don't want to give that up. I don't want to be ant, you know?

Characters.Description: A sad, innocent kid who instead of receiving a female peer's fond embrace or male friend's extended hand, was given a bayonet, some grenades, and all the lonely bunkers and trenches to waste away childhood idealism. His entire service in the armed forces was the unyielding routine and regiment, destruction and death. The poor, hapless soldier lad, who paraded in violent platoons and infantries, an infant himself, sadly endures mornings that melt into evenings with meal breaks of rum and despair. Then, when we hear of his voluntary, premature death we are quick to castigate hims rather than the horrible invention of mankind, war, that forced him to it.

The agitated poet caught in the cares of life finds refuge in the tranquil ambience of a winter scene. Among dead tree limbs and the dearth of vegatation, the speaker feels one with nature's spoils. Rained down by the ills of existence, the lonely poet finds companionship adn belonging in the barren woods. We feel his pain melt away. He soon forgets his strife and becomes engulfed in the merry hum of bee, the feathery snow, the fountain's brink, the fresh, sylvan air, the fringe of summer flowers, the rain that glazed the snow, the massy trunks cased in pure crystal...
Characters.Source: William Cullen Bryant poem, A Winter Piece
Characters.Quote: The time has been that these wild solitudes,/Yet beautiful as wild, were trod by me/Oftener than now; and when the ills of life/Had chafed my spirit--when the unsteady pulse/Beat with strange flutterings--I would wander forth/And seek the woods. The sunshine on my path/Was to me as a friend. The swelling hills,/The quiet dells retiring far between,/With gentle invitation to explore/Their windings, were a calm society/That talked with me and soothed me. Then the chant/Of birds, and chime of brooks, and soft caress/Of the fresh sylvan air, made me forget/The thoughts that broke my peace, and I began/To gather simples by the fountain's brink,/And lose myself in day-dreams.

Characters.Description: A sensitive dame, heart-bleeding and soul-wrenching, from her arch nemesis, Life. Starved and mocked, emotionally battered and bruised, this unnamed narrator yearns for peace and freedom. With all dreams dissolved, all songs quieted, she cries out with all she ever wanted: a childhood home and playing freely in the sun. Lament after lament, she finally escapes out through a certain door. To her great joy and hope, once crushed to dust in life, she finds her house on a hill, a loving father, songs never to be hushed, and a sun always to be enjoyed.
Characters.Source: Edna St. Vincent Millay poem, The Suicide

Characters.Description: The friendly, neighborhood hero who wall crawls and swings off buildings on behalf of New York City. Yet underneath the mask and costume is the scientific-minded Peter Parker filled with insecurities and inadequacies. A nerd who never rose stellar on the job or won the girl is nonetheless the witty Spiderman saving the city of goblins and kingpins. Constantly challenged and tested beyond superhuman endurance, shunned at times by a city, losing loves and friends in an entangled web of mutants and crime, Spiderman fights for the little things: a sick girl, a dedicated co-worker, a lost uncle.

America's well-known nerd who stood up for the millions of highly intelligent pupils with social awkardness. Clad in red suspenders, high-water pants, and thick-rimmed glasses, Steve Urkel has turned the looked down upon geek into a dignified hero. Nonetheless, poor Steve finds himself always stumbling into accidents, mumbling to girls and peers. He suffers frequent ridicules, taunts, and self-inadequacies but his meek, lowly spirit holds a mirror up to human nature, helping to show the narcissitic, egotistic mankind the error of its shallow ways.

Once a determined machine bent on destruction and death, now a learning machine here to serve and protect. From a world of darkness and war, the Terminator must return to a past to save a future. In the gruesome combat against an impossible foe, the Terminator fights to its death, sacrificing himself in the end. Yet he learns along the way the human ways of loyalty, sympathy, and friendship. More than knowledge banks and memory chips in a local mainframe, a soul is present. Who knew robots, machines, could mirror human nature? Who knew a terminator could cherish the value of life?
Characters.Quote: The unknown future rolls toward us. I face it, for the first time, with a sense of hope. Because if a machine, a Terminator, can learn the value of human life, maybe we can too.

Characters.Description: The rock-skin creature of enormous power and strength yet carries a heart bleeding of self-pity. From a radioactive space accident, the Thing formerly Ben Gordon, a normal looking human being has become a pithy, down-to-earth, monstrous crime-stopper. Among a quartet of superheros, the Thing has found his place. But after the clobberin' time, the galaxy wars, the super villains, he feels ugly and ashamed of his appearance. Even with a blind girlfriend who sees his beautiful, noble soul, the Thing feels inadequate. And when told 'beauty lies within', he nods, sighs, and shrugs his shoulders in silence as he walks away.

The always romantic vagabond who turned life's black and white silent show into a rich, colorful golden symphony. Hard-luck by the stringent economic insecurities of the times, this playful little tramp always makes the most of his poor, downtrodden existence. Always a girl's affections to win and a normal life to muster, the lovable tramp frolics and dances into the hearts of many generations. Ultimately, the tramp reminds us all of the unique beauty, long-lasting and worthwhile, that can be found in the dirtiest of slums, the most ragged of people, and the worst conditions of lfie.

The suicidal, young ballerina saved at the last minute. Sunken with the despair of all aimless life and unfortunate family, Thereza is paralyzed in body and mind. But a friend, a stranger, a neighbor, lifts her up and recaptures her desire for life. She slowly gains her walking ability and then the grace of her dancing ability. Through it all she pours out a sad gentleness and re-awakened aura born out of friendship and human care. The spotlight and limelight of show business pales to her spirit. The cheers and applause are hushed to the music of her love. So we watch as she twirls, spins, and sways into our rigid, lackluster hearts.

The sweet, lovable young boy wrought in the deprivation of England's poor. Despite being crippled at birth, Tiny Tim has not proven crippled in heart. With a mild temperament infused with a gentle humor and a benevolent spirit, a sparkling gem grew in the dirty, cold repugnance of urban poverty. A crutch at hand, a loving nature in soul, Tiny Tim has been welcomed by all even ruthless and callous men. He has indeed the child essence of God who sought inexpensive joy with his family and reminds all people who made lame beggars walk and blind men see.
Characters.Quote: He told me, coming home, that he hoped the people saw him in the church, because he was a cripple, and it might be pleasant to them to remember upon Christmas Day, who made lame beggars walk, and blind men see.

Characters.Description: The clean-dressed, eloquent, handsome African American leader of a revolutionary cause who is gunned down by the police on a street on a hot summer day. Part of a Brotherhood to organize a movement and disenfranchised people, Tod Clifton fought hard street corner after street corner until his death. He met his match though on one street corner where Sambo dolls were sold. A policeman with an eager finger put the Harlem youth leader in his place. Tod was an idealistic hope that died young, a hero of a lost cause, a human who died like a dog in a road.
Characters.Quote: Think of your own brother or your cousin John. His lips were thick with an upward curve at the corners. He often smiled. He had good eyes and a pair of fair hands, and he had a heart. He thought about things and he felt deeply. I won’t call him noble because what’s such a word to do with one of us? His name was Clifton, Tod Clifton, and, like any man, he was born of woman to live awhile and fall and die. So that’s his tale to the minute. His name was Clifton and for a while he lived among us and aroused a few hopes in the young manhood of man, and we who knew him loved him and he died...His name was Clifton, Tod Clifton, he was unarmed and his death was as senseless as his life was futile. He had struggled for Brotherhood on a hundred street corners and he thought it would make him more human, but he died like any dog in a road.

Characters.Description: The agitated, middle-aged man who finds himself alienated and on the brink of total failure. Separated from his wife and sons, distanced from a father, Tommy will refute the poet's line -"no man is an island complete unto himself." From an actor to salesman with odd jobs in between, Tommy holds up a disappointing resume of life. And on a Day of Reckoning, he tries desperately with a cold father and shot at the stock market. Thoughts and emotions crowd in him as New York pounds down on him. In the distance is a funeral that carries a message to the iconic middle-class, frustrated man caught on hard times.

A defiant, hateful runaway slave who eventually becomes one of the bravest heroes of the 54th Massachusetts Regiment during the Civil War. Torn into bits and pieces of rage and revenge due to blatant racism, countless lashes from the whip, and ruthless chases by hounds, Trip epitomizes the dispossessed soldier of the Union army. Yet despite the anguish poverty, the Negro ex-slave becomes a noteworthy fighter and learns the everlasting beauty of family and friends and camaraderie. Though he won himself a grave, Trip won the chance to fight against humanity's cruelest system, slavery.
Characters.Quote: I ain't much about no prayin', now. I ain't never had no family, and... killed off my mama. Well, I just... Y'all's the onliest family I got. I love the 54th. Ain't even much a matter what happens tomorrow, 'cause we men, ain't we?

Characters.Description: The weary slave who after a long, ardous day finds peace and solace with a banjo and singing family. An old-fashioned man who would gladly exchange heaven's harps with a country banjo. With a wife, children, and gray-haired granny to sing alongside, we see sorrow, daily cares, aches, pains, troubles, disappear into song and laughter. The whole human saga of pain and joy rings in his heart. The black and white world is colored with tunes. Not minding the poor and rough sound, we learn the breadth and purpose of music; the love of family; the powerful testimony of the poor and meek.
Characters.Source: Paul Laurence Dunbar poem, A Banjo Song

Characters.Description: Caught in an overly scrutinized, dystopic London, Winston moves robotically through the eyes of Big Brother and chase of the Thought Police. Any thought veering out of the groupthink, citizens are apprehended and vaporized. But Winston becomes an unknowing rebel who keeps a personal journal and illicit photograph. Slowly he even melts away his robotic nature for a human soul moved by one innocent note long thought to be alien words -"I love you." Of course, the rebel loses, beaten and tortured to death but an inkling of human consciousness remains.
Characters.Quote: For some reason Winston suddenly found himself thinking of Mrs Parsons, with her wispy hair and the dust in the creases of her face. Within two years those children would be denouncing her to the Thought Police. Mrs Parsons would be vaporized. Syme would be vaporized. Winston would be vaporized. O’Brien would be vaporized. Parsons, on the other hand, would never be vaporized. The eyeless creature with the quacking voice would never be vaporized. The little beetle-like men who scuttle so nimbly through the labyrinthine corridors of Ministries they, too, would never be vaporized. And the girl with dark hair, the girl from the Fiction Department — she would never be vaporized either. It seemed to him that he knew instinctively who would survive and who would perish: though just what it was that made for survival, it was not easy to say.
